segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Good... Are you seeing any change in the way you and I have been talking and feeling since the first day you came here when we went?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, definitely. I think that the first day I came here, I was just like... I've definitely come a long way since the first day I came here.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: You've done what? You've--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I've come a long way, I think. And I don't really know why or how it happened. It makes sense that probably a lot had happened here in therapy. I don't know. I feel like I was having way worse thoughts and way more grim outlook on the world. And even though right now I'm by no means feeling great, I'm definitely not as held up on everything.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: So you're doing a lot better. You're not quite sure why. It may have something to do with--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I feel it in a weird way, I feel like I can come back just around the corner. I don't feel OK about all the things that I didn't feel OK about. It's not like I solved all the things I was uncomfortable with. It's just that I'm not focusing on them as much. I still think about them all the time. I'm just not dwelling on them as much as I did.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Well, let me give you some feedback about how I've been experiencing our sessions.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah. That would be great.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: So here's the way I experienced what's been happening. In the first two, three sessions, I heard this story, a kind of puzzling story that you related to me, which was this-- sorry--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: That's OK.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: --which was this sudden experience of what you called an existential panic. And that sounded right. That's what it sounded like. You were in New York. You suddenly were aware of the mass numbers of people, your insignificance, of the fact that everything was going to end, that everything was transient, that you would die, and along with everyone else. And it was terribly frightening to you. And it was even more puzzling as you described it to me because you had never experienced anything like this before.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: And furthermore, as I started to try to take some history from you in your first sessions, there was this puzzle that you had been extremely happy in your life. You'd had a very good life. And nothing bad had ever happened to you. So that was the way I got-- I

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Would agree with all that stuff.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But then as I experience it, as we went along, things started to change in that way. You related to me that you never even had a fall off your bicycle, that you had good relationships with everyone. Your childhood had been perfect. And maybe that's why this was scaring you so much because everything had been so perfect. But then over these last few sessions, other things started to come up as we talked. I began to get the feeling that you really weren't that happy as a child.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: There were a lot of unhappy things going on, especially last week when we talked about this brace that you had to wear for three years, and how awful that was, and humiliating it was for you in gym class, and things like that. And then I've also-- we haven't explored this in greater depth. But also, things were not always very happy at home, that your mother was pretty unhappy woman, and that she was pretty restrictive. And--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I think she was happy. She was just worried. I don't know if unhappy is the word.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: If she hears a rustling outside in the yard and thinks that's somebody is going to be dead, this sounds like she is not--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: She isn't really...It's weird to me because like she really does worry a lot. But I would never in my life think of her as unhappy because she's so happy. But she's worried.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah, well, being worried and being very happy at the same time, there's some sort of dissonance there.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I agree with what you're saying. But it's so weird.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But you must have seen that as a child and not quite known what to make of this.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: And then that you've had fears before, the fear of flying, for example, which has always been extreme, which-- so my experience then is a progression from this idyllic life, idyllic childhood, gradually hearing more and more and more that it was more and more this stress. And I don't know it you were discovering it now, or realizing it now, or those are things that you really didn't know about, or didn't want to talk about it, or-- so that's puzzling to me.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Do you do you see this progression in our few talks of-- so the more we talk, the more it seemed there was some real unhappiness, more than you recognize at first in your younger life, the pain, the hypochondriasis, fears that you've had?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah. I definitely think that I would agree. But I think I knew it, that I was always-- I don't know if I'm thinking of the word unhappy in the wrong way. But I agree. My whole life, hypochondriasis was a thing, for sure.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: That's not the same as being a very happy child.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: That's true. Yeah, that's true. So then yeah. But then a lot of other things made me really happy. So it didn't take over my happiness like it did with this most recent thing. This most recent thing was-- there's no room for happiness because this was so like scary. Does that make sense?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But it seems thought there's some part of you that wants to perpetuate the idea, the myth maybe that you are an entirely happy person, and things have been very happy all through your life.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Possible, I think you might be right.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: That's going to get in your way in therapy, of course, because in therapy, you want to look very deeply into things.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But the thing is, I don't feel myself like trying to alter.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Oh, I don't think you're doing this.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: That's the part. I feel like, how do I know in my head, I think.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Oh, right. I don't think you're doing this intentionally. It's just this is the what I see as an outsider.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, totally. So how do you figure that out if you don't see it?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: It's one of the reasons that we start to take a more careful history as well as take a look at some dreams, and daydreams that are going on. And the dreams that you've had are by in large not very happy dreams. There's stuff going on in your own conscious that's--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Do a lot of people have really happy dreams all the time though?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: No. Well, they're not necessarily happy dreams. But the dreams are often a way into what with the deeper thoughts are feeling. Any more thoughts about the two of us and how we've been doing and what's been happening in our treatment?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah. I think that-- see, that's what I was saying. I can pinpoint why I'm feeling better. But I know it has to be from coming into here, probably with some other stuff. But I don't really know. I enjoy talking to you, and it's helpful. But I don't know how it's helpful.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Well, can you say more about how you've been experiencing out sessions, or questions you have of me, or thoughts that you've had, or the things we've talked about?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah. I think I've never really done much therapy. So going in, I didn't really know what to expect. And I think I liked the way that you asked me questions of things that I probably would never think about as relevant. But then somehow they became relevant. So I liked that. And I liked that when I asked you about your ideas of death, and why you're not scared of it, or all that stuff that you were open about it. And it was good to hear your perspective in that way.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: And like I totally hear it, and I agree with it. I just-- maybe more now, but not in the beginning-- it was hard for me to feel that way myself. So it's not that I'm puzzled by how you're all OK with it, everyone. I just don't know how to do that. It's still a blocker for me.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah. Yeah. Well, there's a difference between being totally oblivious of it, between that and being aware of death, know it's there, have to cope with it, go on with life, try to get as much our life as you can, and then a continuum between those things, and then being very paralyzed.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Was there anger, harsh words between--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, definitely.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: I didn't know about that. Tell me. Tell me about it.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: There were times when I was just angry, like why can't I just go to the dance and sleep over at the house that everyone's sleeping at? And I never ended up not being able to do it. But it was always like we have to work through it.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But you say that in a pleasant way. Was it always so pleasant in your home when you were talking about this with your mother?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: It was always like. It wasn't necessarily-- well, sometimes it got unpleasant. But it wasn't less unpleasant as it was something to figure out. I always knew one way or another it would work out. But I knew I had to work through it.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Nobody really lost their temper.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: No, not really. But it was more of-- OK, I got the invite to the dance sleepover. And now I know my friends and I am going. I'm going to end up going. But I have to then work through it with my parents. And that was just a little-- an extra annoyance to me.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Was anybody getting angry or losing their temper, your brother, your father, your mother?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I think sometimes my mom did, yeah.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: What was that like?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: It was pretty scary.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Give me an example. Can you?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Gosh, if I can even remember.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Where are you? What year are you talking about when you say scary?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: When I was seven, eight. And maybe my brother did something bad, or lost-- I don't know what he would have done, but she would yell at him maybe. And that I didn't like seeing her so mad.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah. He'd get punished?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Probably, yeah. Probably like to the corner or something, or not.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: I think it's very hard for you to talk about negative things that happened in your family.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I think so. But I think not even just in the family, I think in life. Yes. I have this-- whenever I talk about something negative, I have this feeling of like, but what about all the positive things? I feel almost guilty in a way, because like even not with a family, even if I talk about something negative like, then I think about what about-- how can I even-- there's so much worse that it could have been.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Well, so I'm talking to you and getting some kind of history of your early life. As soon as you say something positive, negative, you're feeling that oh, I'm going to believe now everything was negative, and you've got to reassure me that there were a lot of positive-- why would I think that?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: No, but I think it's less for you and more for me, for my conscience in a way.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Conscience, you mean telling this.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Like knowing, telling, knowing that to myself-- let's say I'm like, oh, yesterday sucked because I couldn't work on a design because the internet was down. And that was a negative thing. But then I feel like I have to say like, oh, but I have a laptop that I own, and a home to do design work in. And I feel like I have to say that after because someone else would not-- why am I complaining? Basically, these are the things I feel like, I have to be--

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But there's a rule around here, floating around in your mind that maybe in the family too, you don't get to complain.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: It's not good to complain, I feel like, because I feel like I'm sitting here, and I'm breathing, and I'm living, and I'm OK.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: As soon as I say something negative, my mind goes to-- well, it could be worse, and think about the good things.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: So we could explore where that came from. Why is it so necessary to instantly say it could have been worse?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Because I feel like then you could get really caught up on negative things.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Who? Me or you?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Me.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: You.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah. I can get really caught up on like-- I don't like to be negative. I don't like to look-- I'd rather look at the positive.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: It we're exploring this in a conversation or a therapy session--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, that's what you have to do is explore the negative.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: You really have to do it. But you're saying it's quite hard. It's really ingrained. There's some sort of voice in you saying don't talk about the bad things.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, or if you do talk about the bad things, don't forget about the good ones.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah, right. And that's what I think you've really got to work on in therapy in the future.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I think that's a good point.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah, you're not going to be-- because that's what happened with us. I thought, I'm baffled here. Here's a girl who had an ideal childhood.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But I still think it was. I still think that there were bad things, negative things, but overall, ideal

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yeah.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Because there could have been other worse negative things, and I'm OK.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Sure. You could have been a slave in a galley pulling oars all day.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I could have, or I could have been abused, or I could have not-- or all lived in one bedroom, check to check.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But once again, you've got the strong message that you got to look at the bright side of things. You can't complain.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, but I don't think that's wrong, is it, to look at the bright side of things?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: It is if you're going to get involved in really examining yourself and your life in therapy.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: That's true, because it's about digging.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Well, this is exactly what's happened to us in our discussions. I'm left scratching my head every session. I'm just like, this doesn't make sense. She's never even fallen off a bike. Nothing that--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But I haven't.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Well, I'm using it as a metaphor, that nothing--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But I've never had surgery. I've never-- I've never--

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: See, I think you're doing it again now.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I think I am.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: There can be a lot of pain in a family, a lot of unhappiness without there having to be major surgery, or manage your fall off a bike or whatever. It can be very subtle in a way. And this is not a kind of indictment of anybody, of your parents, or you, your brother. We're interested really in what your experience is. And I think you conceal even almost from yourself what your experiences were.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Or maybe also that I'm looking at it as every family has their things. Isn't that just what family is? I don't know. Maybe not.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But we're looking at your family now.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, that's true.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But once again, you're saying every family has their thing. It's almost as though you're a defense attorney.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I think you're right.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: And you're arguing when no one is really making any accusations.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: I think that it's all towards myself, not towards you.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Right.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But yeah, I think so.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: And OK.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Or maybe it's because-- sorry-- I think maybe it's because I'm feeling so down right now that any other negativity, I don't want to bring anymore-- I'm trying to stay, not see the negative things maybe.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Right, but that puts you into almost a game world, and what you're talking about is not really the way that life really is for you in your past.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Would you feel guilty, feeling that you're betraying your family, or your father, or your mother?

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I think in a way I do feel guilty. I think, yeah, because--

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Ungrateful and unappreciative.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: In a way, yeah. because it's like if I say-- I feel like saying oh, if my mom was worried a lot all the time, and that was negative for me, but then inside of me I want to say but yeah, of course she was probably worried and stressed because she was doing all of these 500 things, and moved to this whole new country for you to have a good life, and she tried to give you everything she had. She's not a robot. She's a human. How could you even look at her like that?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: But it's not a courtroom. We're not looking for blame.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: It's like my feeling, conscious.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: There's no doubt what you're saying is true. Your mother is passing along to you what's been passed on to her. And her job really here is to break this cycle so that you're not putting--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Passing on what part of it?

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Passing on her pain, passing on her anguish. That didn't spring up de novo in her obviously came from her experience from before. And then her grandparents had this experience with their great grandparent. So it's all being passed on. What we're trying to do is to change things so that if you have family, you're not going to be passing on whatever this is.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But there's some things that I do want to pass on. To my kids, I want to pass on looking at the bright side of things.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Sure. Sure.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: When you feel sad about something, feel sad. But remember that it could be worse. I actually don't think-- I think that we were right, that me in a therapy session and avoiding it is bad. But I do still the quality that I have of always being the most positive I can.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Yes, that's fine. But if I'm going to explore your sadness, we're going to find out, understand what your sadness is about. I have to shout awful loud, shout louder than this voice than you're saying--

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, that's true.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: --well, other people are sadder, or it's not so bad.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: But I feel it.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: I know. So that's what we're going to call the resistance in therapy. It's going to be getting in the way. And so I have to keep this very much in mind.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: OK. That's very eye opening, because I don't think I really realize myself doing it until you pointed it out.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: It's very powerful.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: It's very powerful.

segments.speaker: client
segments.content: Yeah, I really didn't, because I don't feel myself fighting. I just feel myself telling you my thoughts.

segments.speaker: therapist
segments.content: Well, you are. But there are two opposing kinds of thoughts going on. One is your pain, and there's another voice saying, oh, it's not so bad. Other people have it worse. And that's the kind of thing we've got to really look at so we can really get to some of the bottom of your pain.
